ETOMIDATE

  • Indications and doses
  • Pregnancy
  • Hepatic impairment

  • Important safety information
  • Cautions
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Induction of anaesthesia,

By slow intravenous injection

  • For adults
    150–300 micrograms/kg (max. per dose 60 mg), to be administered over 30-60 seconds (over 60 seconds in patients in whom hypotension might be hazardous).
  • For adults elderly
    150–200 micrograms/kg (max. per dose 60 mg), to be administered over 30-60 seconds (over 60 seconds in patients in whom hypotension might be hazardous).

Advice when patient is pregnant

May depress neonatal respiration if used during delivery.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Reduce dose in liver cirrhosis.

Known side effects

General side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: Apnoea, hyperventilation, hypotension, nausea, rash, stridor, vomiting,

uncommon: Arrhythmias, cough, hiccups, hypersalivation, hypertension, phlebitis,

notKnown: AV block, cardiac arrest, extraneous muscle movement (high incidence), pain on injection, respiratory depression, seizures, shivering, Stevens-Johnson syndrome,

Pain on injection

Can be reduced by injecting into a larger vein or by giving an opioid analgesic just before induction.

Extraneous muscle movement

Extraneous muscle movements can be minimised by an opioid analgesic or a short-acting benzodiazepine given just before induction.

Directions for administration

To be administered over 30–60 seconds (over 60 seconds in patients in whom hypotension might be hazardous).

Advice for patients and carers

Important safety information

Etomidate should only be administered by, or under the direct supervision of, personnel experienced in its use, with adequate training in anaesthesia and airway management, and when resuscitation equipment is available.

Cautions regarding administration

  • Acute porphyrias (avoid)
  • acute circulatory failure (shock)
  • adrenal insufficiency
  • cardiovascular disease
  • elderly
  • fixed cardiac output
  • hypovolaemia

  • Etomidate suppresses adrenocortical function, particularly during continuous administration, and it should not be used for maintenance of anaesthesia. It should be used with caution in patients with underlying adrenal insufficiency, for example, those with sepsis.

Prepared medicinal forms of ETOMIDATE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Solution for injection
Emulsion for injection
